entry.title: Combined summary - Newly introduced DoS
entry.summary: In a discussion on the Bitcoin developers mailing list, Gavin Andresen and Luke-Jr debated whether certain DoS (Denial of Service) rules that are currently in place should be removed. They discussed three cases where DoS rules could potentially prevent relaying or accepting valid transactions/blocks.The first case involved a transaction with a non-standard SigOp count that would be allowed in blocks but not accepted by the mainline rules; it was argued that it shouldn't be punished. The second case questioned whether a coinbase maturity DoS limit should have a chance of immediately kicking the node, noting that rejecting these transactions is cheap, while a small DoS score seems reasonable. The third case questioned whether prev block not found errors in AcceptBlock() should be DoSed, which Andresen believed should stay as it is a subtle bug that attackers look for and the DoS penalty is appropriate.Luke-Jr suggested creating a global flag to indicate when a node is current with the network, which would help prevent these types of attacks. Additionally, there is discussion about the coinbase maturity DoS limit and how rejecting these transactions is relatively cheap. Finally, there is a brief exchange regarding an attacker using differences in transaction confirmations to get nodes to ban each other.Andresen argued that some cases are impossible to trigger, but it is appropriate to keep the check and DoS penalty in place because attackers look for subtle bugs and edge cases that can be exploited. He also discussed the possibility of triggering a DoS penalty when a peer has a huge number of blocks than you, stating that it is a "can't never happen but we'll wear a belt-and-suspenders just in case" case. Overall, they agreed that certain DoS rules need to be kept in place to prevent network attacks.In a discussion thread from September 2011, Bitcoin developers Luke-Jr and Gavin Andresen discussed the possibility of punishing non-standard transaction relaying and coinbase maturity DoS limits. While Luke-Jr believed that such punishments were unnecessary and could open up the network to DoS attacks, Andresen argued that failing hard on outdated clients was preferable to allowing them to continue with a non-majority blockchain. The two also debated whether or not it made sense for the DoS code to kick in if someone spent a coinbase with more confirmations than the node had seen. Andresen argued that if this were the case, there were bigger problems to worry about and it was reasonable for the DoS code to kick either the user or the node off the network.
